    </ul></div>
</div>

<div class="portletWrapper" data-portlethash="706c6f6e652e7269676874636f6c756d6e0a636f6e746578740a2f4850534d41494e2f73747564792f67726164756174652f7068640a666f722d63757272656e742d7068642d73747564656e7473" id="portletwrapper-706c6f6e652e7269676874636f6c756d6e0a636f6e746578740a2f4850534d41494e2f73747564792f67726164756174652f7068640a666f722d63757272656e742d7068642d73747564656e7473"><div class="campl-content-container falcon-linkbox-portlet">
    <div class="campl-heading-container">
        <h2>For current PhD students</h2>
        
    </div>
    <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-related-links"><li><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/students/phd-guide">PhD students' guide</a></li>
        
    </ul></div>
</div>

$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});

    <div class="campl-search-input">
      <form action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
      
        <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></form>

			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>

					<p class="campl-page-title">Department of History and Philosophy of Science</p>

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>

                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-772226c2f1d04a6dbb6796430cbb8d4a">
            <p><em>Please <a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/about/contact" class="internal-link" target="_self">contact the Department</a> if you would like to update or correct the information about you on this page or if you would like to join our alumni email list.</em></p>
<h2 class="clear">2017</h2>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Feraz Azhar</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Probabilistic reasoning in the inflationary universe<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Postdoctoral Fellow, Black Hole Initiative, Harvard University</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Tillmann Taape</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Hieronymus Brunschwig and the making of vernacular medical knowledge in early German print<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Postdoctoral Fellowship, Columbia University</p>
</div>
<h2 class="clear">2016</h2>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Leah Astbury</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Breeding women and lusty infants in seventeenth-century England<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Wellcome Trust Fellow, HPS Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Megan Barford</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Naval hydrography, charismatic bureaucracy and the British military state, 1825–1855<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Curator of Cartography, Royal Museums Greenwich, London</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Riana Betzler</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Why empathy? The pernicious consequences of conceptual confusion in empathy research<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Postdoctoral Fellow, Konrad Lorenz Institute for Evolution and Cognition Research</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Andrew Buskell</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Modelling culture: a philosophical examination of cultural dynamics and cultural evolution<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Associate, LSE London<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Research Associate, HPS Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Seb Falk</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> <a href="https://www.repository.cam.ac.uk/handle/1810/256996">Improving instruments: equatoria, astrolabes and the practices of monastic astronomy in late medieval England</a><br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Fellow, Girton College, Cambridge</p>
</div>
<h2 class="clear">2015</h2>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Iris Montero Sobrevilla</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Transatlantic hum: natural history and the itineraries of the torpid hummingbird<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Mellon Postdoctoral Fellow in the Humanities, Brown University</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Dmitriy Myelnikov</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> <a href="https://www.repository.cam.ac.uk/handle/1810/252737">Transforming mice: technique and communication in the making of transgenic animals, 1974–1988</a><br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Postdoctoral Researcher, University of Edinburgh<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Research Associate, University of Manchester</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Eoin Phillips</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Making time fit: astronomers, artisans and the state, 1770–1820<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Associate, Longitude Project, HPS Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Postdoctoral Fellow, CEHIC, Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>James Poskett</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Metropole of the mind: phrenology and the making of a global science, 1815–1923<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Adrian Research Fellow, Darwin College, Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Assistant Professor, History, University of Warwick</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Kathryn Schoefert</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> The view from the psychiatric laboratory: the research of Ernst Grünthal and his mid-twentieth-century peers<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Researcher, Generation to Reproduction Project, HPS Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Research and Teaching Associate, King's College London</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Sophie Waring</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Thomas Young, the Board of Longitude and the age of reform<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Modern Collections Curator, Museum of the History of Science, Oxford<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Curator of Chemistry, Science Museum, London</p>
</div>
<h2 class="clear">2014</h2>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Shahar Avin</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> <a href="https://www.repository.cam.ac.uk/handle/1810/247434">Breaking the grant cycle: on the rational allocation of public resources to scientific research projects</a><br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Software Engineer, Google UK Ltd<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Postdoctoral Researcher, Centre for the Study of Existential Risk, University of Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Sophie Brockmann</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Surveying nature: the creation and communication of natural-historical knowledge in Enlightenment Central America<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Lecturer in Integrated Studies, University of Pennsylvania<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Early Career Academic Fellow, De Montfort University, Leicester</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Will Carruthers</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Egyptology, archaeology and the making of revolutionary Egypt, c.1925–1958<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Max Weber Programme Postdoctoral Fellow, Department of History and Civilization, European University Institute, Florence<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Gerda Henkel Stiftung Postdoctoral Research Scholar/Visiting Scholar, German Historical Institute, London</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Sean Dyde</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Brains, minds and nerves in British medicine and physiology, 1764–1852<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Postdoctoral Fellowship, Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, Berlin<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Marie Curie Research Fellow, University of Leeds</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Ruth Horry</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Transitions and transformations in Assyriology, c.1880–1913: artefacts, academics and museums<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Associate, AHRC Scholarly Libraries project, University of Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Curator, Wellcome Collection, London</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Josh Nall</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> News from Mars: transatlantic mass media and the practice of new astronomy, 1870–1910<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Assistant Curator, Whipple Museum, HPS Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Jesse Olszynko-Gryn</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Pregnancy testing in Britain, c. 1900–67: laboratories, animals and demand from doctors, patients and consumers<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Associate, Generation to Reproduction project, HPS Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Wellcome Research Fellow, HPS Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Emma Perkins</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Non haberi sed esse: Tycho Brahe's self-presentation through visual and material culture<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Associate, AHRC Diagrams Project, HPS Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Affiliated Scholar, HPS Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Arianne Shahvisi</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> On the nature and origins of thermodynamic asymmetry<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Assistant Professor, Philosophy, American University of Beirut<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Lecturer in Medical Ethics and Humanities, Brighton and Sussex Medical School</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Lena Zuchowski</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> On the foundations of chaos and complexity: definitions and differentiations<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Assistant Professor, University of Salzburg</p>
</div>
<h2 class="clear">2013</h2>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Alexandra Bacopoulos-Viau</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Scripting the mind: automatic writing in France, 1857–1930<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Postdoctoral Fellow, History, New York University<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Banting Postdoctoral Fellow, McGill University</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Jenny Bangham</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Blood groups and the rise of human genetics in mid-twentieth century Britain<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research scholar, Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, Berlin<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Wellcome Fellow, HPS Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Katy Barrett</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> The wanton line: Hogarth and the public life of longitude<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Curator of Art, Royal Museums Greenwich, London</p>
</div>

<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> What theory cannot capture: Freud and four philosophers on humour<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> University Lecturer in Philosophy, University of Cape Town</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Anna Mayer</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Roots of the history of science in Britain, 1916–1950<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Fellow, University of Florida<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Research Fellow, Contemporary Scientific Archives Centre, Bath</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Kemal de Soysa</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Using globes and celestial planispheres in Restoration England<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> International equity research firm, Sri Lanka<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Independent Non-Executive Director, Nations Trust Bank PLC</p>
</div>
<h2 class="clear">2003</h2>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Susan Gamble</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> The hologram and its antecedents, 1891–1965: the illusory history of a three-dimensional illusion<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Independent artist</p>
</div>
<h2 class="clear">2002</h2>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Charlotte Bigg</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Behind the lines: spectroscopic enterprises in early twentieth-century Europe<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Fellowship, Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, Berlin<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Chargée de recherche (permanent senior research fellow), CNRS, Centre Alexandre Koyré, Paris</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Rachel Cooper</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Classifying madness: a philosophical examination of the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Lecturer, Philosophy, Lancaster University<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Senior Lecturer, Philosophy, Lancaster University</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Jim Endersby</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Putting plants in their place: Joseph Hooker's philosophical botany, 1838–1865<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Postdoctoral Research Fellow, Darwin College, Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Reader, History of Science, University of Sussex</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Gerald Kutcher</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Clinical ethics and research imperatives in human radiation experiments: a case of contested conduct<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Assistant Professor, History of Science, Technology and Medicine, SUNY Binghamton<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Professor, History of Science, Technology and Medicine, SUNY Binghamton</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Wen-Ji Wang</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> A genealogy for the psychoanalyst: <em>Bildung</em>, experiment, and the training of the psychoanalyst<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Postdoctoral Fellowship, Institute of History and Philology, Academia Sinica, Taiwan<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Associate Professor, Institute of Science, Technology and Society, National Yang-Ming University, Taiwan</p>
</div>
<h2 class="clear">2001</h2>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Anjan Chakravartty</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Semirealism: the metaphysical foundations of scientific realism<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Assistant Professor, Department of Philosophy, University of Toronto<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Professor and Director, John J. Reilly Center for Science, Technology and Values, Notre Dame, USA</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Talal Debs</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Representation and symmetry: an analysis of the tension between objectivity and conventionality in modern physics<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Associate, Centre for Philosophy of Natural and Social Science, LSE<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Executive Director, JP Morgan, NY</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Cathy Gere</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Psyche's labyrinth: Minoan archaeology and modern prophecy, 1900–1945<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Wellcome Trust Research Associate, King's College, Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Associate Professor, History and Science Studies, University of California, San Diego</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Christopher Haley</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Envisioning the unseen universe: models of the ether in the nineteenth century<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Departmental Archivist and Historian, Department of Chemistry, University of Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Executive Director, Policy and Research, Nesta, London</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Anandi Hattiangadi</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Oughts and thoughts: scepticism and the normativity of content<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Lecturer in Philosophy, University of<br />Oxford; Tutorial Fellow, St Hilda's College, Oxford<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Professor in Philosophy, Stockholm University; Pro<br />Futura Scientia Fellow, Swedish Collegium of Advanced Studies</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Tim Lewens</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Organisms and artefacts – design in nature and elsewhere<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> University Lecturer, HPS Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Professor, HPS Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Michael Rich</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> The passing of miracles: anti-realism and the success of science<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Local government, UK</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Eugenia Roldan Vera</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Book export and the transmission of knowledge from Britain to early-independent Spanish America<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Humboldt Postdoctoral Fellowship, Centre for Comparative Education, Humboldt University, Berlin<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Professor, Department of Educational Research, Cinvestav, Mexico City</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Sujit Sivasundaram</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Nature speaks theology: colonialism, cultivation, conversion and the Pacific, 1795–1850<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Research Fellow, Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Reader in World History, Faculty of History, University of Cambridge</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>John Tresch</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Mechanical romanticism: engineers of the artificial paradise<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Assistant Professor, History and Sociology of Science, University of Pennsylvania</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Joerg Tuske</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Is emotion the colour of thought? Philosophical reflections<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Assistant Editor, Wittgenstein Archive, Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Professor, Philosophy, Salisbury University, Maryland, USA</p>
</div>
<div class="placement-item">
<h3>Karin Tybjerg</h3>
<p><strong>Thesis:</strong> Doing philosophy with machines: Hero of Alexandria's rhetoric of mechanics in relation to the contemporary philosophy<br /><strong>Placement after PhD:</strong> Moses and Mary Finley Research Fellowship, Darwin College, Cambridge<br /><strong>Last known:</strong> Associate Professor, Medical Museion, University of Copenhagen</p>
</div>
            
        </div>

$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});

				<div class="campl-site-search" id="site-search-btn">
    <label for="header-search" class="hidden">Search site</label>
    <div class="campl-search-input">
      <form action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
      
        <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></form>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix campl-page-sub-title campl-recessed-sub-title">
			<div class="campl-column3 campl-spacing-column">
				 
			</div>
			<div class="campl-column9">
				<div class="campl-content-container">
					<h1 class="campl-sub-title">
                    Why study HPS at Cambridge?
                </h1>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div><div class="campl-row campl-content campl-recessed-content">
			<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
				<div class="campl-column3">
					
  <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation">
    <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation-structure">
      <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb"><li><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk" title="Department of History and Philosophy of Science">
            Department of History and Philosophy of Science
            <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
        </a></li>
        
          <li>
            <a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study" class="campl-parent-page" title="Study HPS">
              Study HPS
              <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
            </a>
          </li>
        
      </ul><ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-navigation"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate"><span>Undergraduate study</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate"><span>Graduate study</span></a>
<ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-children navTree navTreeLevel1"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate/why-cambridge" class=" navTreeCurrentItem"><span>Why study HPS at Cambridge?</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate/mphil-hpsm"><span>MPhil in History and Philosophy of Science and Medicine</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate/mphil-hms"><span>MPhil in Health, Medicine and Society</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate/phd"><span>PhD in History and Philosophy of Science</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate/funding"><span>Funding for graduate students</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate/faqs"><span>Frequently asked questions</span></a>
</li>
</ul></li>

      </ul></div>
  </div>

				</div>
				<div class="campl-column6  campl-main-content" id="campl-content"><div class="clearfix campl-carousel" id="campl-carousel">
        
          <div class="campl-carousel-container">
            <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-slides"><li class="campl-slide campl-column12">
  <div class="image-container">
    
      <img alt="front-door.jpg" class="campl-scale-with-grid" src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/carousel/front-door/@@images/b5744351-78ba-4108-984e-d6a4d7b2eb45.jpeg" title="The front door of the Department" /></div>
  

</li>
            </ul></div>
        
      </div><div class="campl-content-container">

            <div id="viewlet-above-content">
</div>

            
                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-506e8ac08f94448dbbe3a24e6875906e">
            <p class="first">History and philosophy of science offer powerful approaches to interpreting knowledge. The Department of History and Philosophy of Science at the University of Cambridge is the largest institution of its kind in the UK and has an outstanding international reputation for teaching and research. Human and material resources are excellent.</p>
<p>Specialist staff teach a wide range of subjects across the history, philosophy and sociology of the sciences and medicine. The environment is exemplary in the number of externally-funded research groups, the lively community of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, and the active programme of research seminars and reading groups. HPS also has close links to other university institutions across the medical, natural and social sciences, the arts and the humanities, including through the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities, and to the Needham Research Institute, the leading Western centre for the history of science, technology and medicine in East Asia.</p>
<p>Located in the heart of Cambridge, the Department is centred on the Whipple Museum, a world-class collection of scientific instruments, and the Whipple Library, the largest specialist library in history and philosophy of science and medicine in the UK. The holdings of this and the other Cambridge libraries, including the University Library, are among the richest in the world.</p>
<p>The pass rate in all courses approaches 100%, and in recent years about 80% of successful doctoral students have taken posts in the field of HPS. Students go on to a wide range of careers, from academic work in universities, museums and libraries to science journalism and consultancy.</p>
<p><span class="campl-icon campl-info-icon"><a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate/phd/placement-record" class="internal-link" target="_self">PhD placement record</a></span></p>
<div class="info-box-full">
<h2 style="padding-top: 0; ">Key research areas</h2>
<ul><li>History of medicine (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/brazelton" target="_self" title="">Mary Brazelton</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/hopwood" target="_self" title="">Nick Hopwood</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/kassell" target="_self" title="">Lauren Kassell</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/margocsy" target="_self" title="">Dániel Margócsy</a>)</li>
<li>History of the physical sciences (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/jardine" target="_self" title="">Nick Jardine</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/schaffer" target="_self" title="">Simon Schaffer</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/staley" target="_self" title="">Richard Staley</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/taub" target="_self" title="">Liba Taub</a>)</li>
<li>History of the life and earth sciences (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/curry" target="_self" title="">Helen Curry</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/hopwood" target="_self" title="">Nick Hopwood</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/jardine" target="_self" title="">Nick Jardine</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/secord" target="_self" title="">Jim Secord</a>)</li>
<li>History of agriculture and environmental history (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/curry" target="_self" title="">Helen Curry</a>)</li>
<li>History of instruments (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/schaffer" target="_self" title="">Simon Schaffer</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/taub" target="_self" title="">Liba Taub</a>)</li>
<li>History of science communication (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/hopwood" target="_self" title="">Nick Hopwood</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/secord" target="_self" title="">Jim Secord</a>)</li>
<li>General philosophy of science (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/chang" target="_self" title="">Hasok Chang</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/halina" target="_self" title="">Marta Halina</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/lewens" target="_self" title="">Tim Lewens</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/stegenga" target="_self" title="">Jacob Stegenga</a>)</li>
<li>Philosophy of social and psychological sciences (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/alexandrova" target="_self" title="">Anna Alexandrova</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/halina" target="_self" title="">Marta Halina</a>)</li>
<li>Philosophy of biology (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/halina" target="_self" title="">Marta Halina</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/lewens" target="_self" title="">Tim Lewens</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/stegenga" target="_self" title="">Jacob Stegenga</a>)</li>
<li>Philosophy of physics (<a class="external-link" href="http://trin-hosts.trin.cam.ac.uk/fellows/butterfield/" target="_self" title="">Jeremy Butterfield</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/chang" target="_self" title="">Hasok Chang</a>)</li>
<li>Bioethics and public health ethics (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/john" target="_self" title="">Stephen John</a>, <a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/lewens" target="_self" title="">Tim Lewens)</a></li>
<li>Sociology of science (<a class="external-link" href="http://www.people.hps.cam.ac.uk/schaffer" target="_self" title="">Simon Schaffer</a>)</li>
</ul></div>
<p style="padding-top: 1.5em; ">The Department has a long and distinguished tradition in <a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/medicine" class="internal-link" target="_self">history of medicine</a> and is a major centre of teaching and research in the field. Expertise in medical history covers an exceptionally wide range, from antiquity to the present, from the medieval universities to the postwar laboratory sciences, from anatomy to psychoanalysis. Students have the opportunity both to focus on history of medicine, and to take advantage of intellectual exchange with colleagues in related areas.</p>
<h2>Lectures, seminars and reading groups</h2>
<p>A lively programme of research seminars and reading groups makes the Department a hive of intellectual activity. In addition to the weekly departmental seminar, there are regular specialist research seminars and reading groups on history of medicine, history of natural history, 20th-century science, philosophy of science, philosophy and history of physics, philosophy of psychology, and science and literature. Regular workshops allow graduate students to present and discuss work in progress.</p>
<p>Students are entitled to attend any undergraduate lectures in the University.</p>
<h2>Libraries</h2>
<p>Cambridge has excellent library resources for history and philosophy of science and medicine. The Department's own Whipple Library was founded on Robert S Whipple's collection of rare scientific books and includes over 10,000 such volumes, some dating back to the 15th century.</p>
<p>The University Library is entitled to a copy of every print publication from the UK and Ireland. It has over 8 million books and journals, among them many early printed books. Manuscripts include the papers of Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, James Clerk Maxwell, Lord Kelvin, George Stokes, JJ Thomson and Ernest Rutherford, and of major scientific institutions in the University. Other departmental and faculty libraries and the College libraries house many valuable resources.</p>
<h2>Museums</h2>
<p>The Department is unusual in having teaching programmes connected to a world-class collection of scientific instruments, models and books – the Whipple Museum of the History of Science, the gift of RS Whipple to the University in 1944. Instruments of astronomy, navigation, surveying, drawing and calculating are well represented in the collection, as are sundials, mathematical instruments and early electrical apparatus.</p>
<p>Students are actively encouraged to work with objects in the Whipple Museum. Graduate students have the opportunity to produce case studies to display their current research.</p>
<p>Several other University museums are also important resources for studies in history of science, including the Sedgwick Museum of Earth Sciences and the Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology.</p>
<h2>Languages and palaeography</h2>
<p>The University Language Centre offers courses in 140 modern languages at basic and intermediate levels. Latin and Greek courses are offered by the Faculty of Classics. Several departments offer palaeography courses. (You may need to sign up early for some of these.)</p>
<p>The Department has its own informal reading groups for Latin and Greek, which help beginners and experts with translations.</p>
            
        </div>
    
    

                             </div>

					<ul class="campl-unstyled-list">

						<li>
							<a href="http://www.cam.ac.uk/research/research-at-cambridge">About research at Cambridge</a>
						</li>
					</ul>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>	
	</div>

					    
	<!-- .campl-global-footer ends --><!--[if lte IE 8]>
</div>
<![endif]--><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/libs/ios-orientationchange-fix.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/libs/modernizr.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/custom.js"></script><script type="text/javascript">
$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});
</script></body></html>

        <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></form>

			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>

<li>
<a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/medicine">History of Medicine</a>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix campl-page-sub-title campl-recessed-sub-title">
			<div class="campl-column3 campl-spacing-column">
				 
			</div>
			<div class="campl-column9">
				<div class="campl-content-container">
					<h1 class="campl-sub-title">
                     Undergraduate study
                </h1>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div><div class="campl-row campl-content campl-recessed-content">
			<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
				<div class="campl-column3">
					
  <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation">
    <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation-structure">
      <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb"><li><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk" title="Department of History and Philosophy of Science">
            Department of History and Philosophy of Science
            <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
        </a></li>
        
          <li>
            <a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study" class="campl-parent-page" title="Study HPS">
              Study HPS
              <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
            </a>
          </li>
        
      </ul><ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-navigation"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate" class=" navTreeCurrentItem"><span>Undergraduate study</span></a>
<ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-children navTree navTreeLevel1"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/introducing"><span>Introducing History and Philosophy of Science</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/students"><span>What our students say</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/faqs"><span>Frequently asked questions</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/routes"><span>Routes into History and Philosophy of Science</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partib"><span>Part IB</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partii"><span>Part II</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partiii"><span>Part III</span></a>
</li>
</ul></li>

</li>

      </ul></div>
  </div>

				</div>
				<div class="campl-column6  campl-main-content" id="campl-content"><div class="clearfix campl-carousel" id="campl-carousel">
        
          <div class="campl-carousel-container">
            <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-slides"><li class="campl-slide campl-column12">
  <div class="image-container">
    
      <img alt="darwin-caricature.jpg" class="campl-scale-with-grid" src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/carousel/darwin-caricature/@@images/0f2ef16a-4f51-4453-8ebe-eb4067a42219.jpeg" title="Caricature of Charles Darwin (London Sketchbook, 1874)" /></div>
  

</li>
            </ul></div>
        
      </div><div class="campl-content-container">

            <div id="viewlet-above-content">
</div>

            
                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-8f71ff45dbc047a6abe17f078d9fc3ec">
            <p>History and Philosophy of Science is available as an option for students in their <a title="Part IB" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partib" class="internal-link" target="_self">second</a>, <a title="Part II" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partii" class="internal-link" target="_self">third</a> and <a title="Part III" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partiii" class="internal-link" target="_self">fourth</a> year at Cambridge.</p>
<p>On these pages you will find an <a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/introducing" class="internal-link" target="_self">introduction</a> to the subject, answers to some <a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/faqs" class="internal-link" target="_self">frequently asked questions</a>, and an outline of the different <a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/routes" class="internal-link" target="_self">routes into HPS</a>.</p>
<p>For information about applying to Cambridge, please see the University's <a href="http://www.undergraduate.study.cam.ac.uk/">Undergraduate Admissions</a> website.</p>
            
        </div>
    
    

                             </div>
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-body">





    <div class="visualClear"><!-- --></div>

    <div class="documentActions">
        

        

    </div>

</div>

                            
                        </div>
                    

                    
                </div>
            

            <div id="viewlet-below-content">





</div>
        </div></div>
				<div class="campl-column3 campl-secondary-content">
            
                
<div class="portletWrapper" data-portlethash="706c6f6e652e7269676874636f6c756d6e0a636f6e746578740a2f4850534d41494e2f73747564792f756e64657267726164756174652f756e64657267726164756174652d6f766572766965770a706f72746c65745f7374617469632d31" id="portletwrapper-706c6f6e652e7269676874636f6c756d6e0a636f6e746578740a2f4850534d41494e2f73747564792f756e64657267726164756174652f756e64657267726164756174652d6f766572766965770a706f72746c65745f7374617469632d31">
<div class="campl-content-container falcon-static-portlet">
  <div class="portlet-static"><blockquote class="clearfix embed-quote-full">
<p class="campl-quote-mark">I enjoyed every minute of working in this friendly, supportive and vibrant department. HPS has something for everyone and I thoroughly recommend it.</p>
</blockquote>
<p><a class="internal-link campl-primary-cta" href="resolveuid/eff6c831f9af402bbf433a3b7ae744e8" target="_self" title="">More comments from our students</a></p></div>
  
</div>



</div>




            
        </div>

$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});

            }
        });
        </script><meta name="DC.creator" content="dt243@cam.ac.uk" /><meta name="DC.format" content="text/html" /><meta name="DC.language" content="en" /><meta name="DC.date.modified" content="2016-08-25T08:52:34+00:00" /><meta name="DC.date.created" content="2016-07-14T13:36:39+00:00" /><meta name="DC.type" content="Page" /><meta name="DC.distribution" content="Global" /><meta name="robots" content="ALL" /><meta name="distribution" content="Global" /></head><body class="template-document_view portaltype-document site-HPSMAIN section-study subsection-undergraduate subsection-undergraduate-faqs icons-on userrole-anonymous campl-theme-1"><!--[if lt IE 7]>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">	
			<div class="campl-header-container campl-column8" id="global-header-controls">
				<a href="http://www.cam.ac.uk" class="campl-main-logo">
					<img alt="University of Cambridge" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/main-logo-small.png" /></a>

				<ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-horizontal-navigation campl-global-navigation clearfix" id="primary-nav"><li>

			<div class="campl-column2">
				
				<div class="campl-site-search" id="site-search-btn">
    <label for="header-search" class="hidden">Search site</label>
    <div class="campl-search-input">
      <form action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
      
        <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></form>
    </div>
  </div>
			</div>
		</div>		
	</div><div class="campl-row campl-global-header campl-search-drawer">
		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>
	</div>

                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-fbcab76415db4ee880c7809c4a299ae0">
            <p><strong>When can I study History and Philosophy of Science?</strong></p>
<ul><li><strong>Natural Sciences Tripos:</strong> You can choose HPS as one of your three Part IB subjects and then as your full-time Part II subject. We also offer a Part III course.</li>
<li><strong>Other Triposes:</strong> HPS papers can be taken as part of the HSPS (Human, Social and Political Sciences) or PBS (Psychological and Behavioural Sciences) Tripos. Part IIA students can choose either of the HPS Part IB papers. Part IIB students can choose from some of the HPS Part II papers: see <a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/students/timetable/partii/single" class="internal-link" target="_self">single-paper options</a>.</li>
</ul><p><strong>I'm thinking about taking Biological and Biomedical Sciences for Part II. Can I study HPS as part of this course?</strong></p>
<p>Yes, we offer three <a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/students/timetable/partii/single" class="internal-link" target="_self">single-paper options</a> to students taking the NST Part II course in Biological and Biomedical Sciences.</p>
<p><strong>Can I take the full-time HPS Part II or Part III course if I'm not a Natural Sciences student?</strong></p>
<p>Yes, but you will need to switch to the Natural Sciences Tripos. You should ask your Director of Studies about the procedure for doing this.</p>
<p><strong>Can I study HPS Part II if I didn't take HPS Part IB?</strong></p>
<p>Yes, HPS Part II is open to students who have not taken HPS Part IB.</p>
<p><strong>How do I apply to take HPS Part IB or Part II? Do I need to fill in a form?</strong></p>
<p>There is no application form; you just need to register your choice on CamSIS.</p>
<p><strong>Is there a limit on the number of students who can take HPS?</strong></p>
<p>There is no limit on the number of students who can take the HPS Part IB option, but we have a limit of 40 for HPS Part II and 12 for Part III.</p>
<p><strong>What if HPS Part II is oversubscribed? How do you decide which students to take?</strong></p>
<p>If you have taken HPS Part IB, we will make our decision on your performance in the HPS exams. If you have not taken HPS Part IB, we will look at your exam results, but we may also ask you to write a short statement that describes your academic background to date and explains why you want to take HPS Part II. We will contact you in mid-June to let you know if you have a place on the course.</p>
<p><strong>And what if HPS Part III is oversubscribed? How do you decide which students to take?</strong></p>
<p>We will look at your exam results and your statement of interests. We may also invite you to an interview.</p>
<p><strong>I'm not used to writing essays. Will I find HPS too difficult?</strong></p>
<p>Essay writing – structuring arguments clearly and effectively – is an important part of what the courses are about. But we realise that most students coming to HPS have not written a connected piece of prose in a long time, so our supervisors are always ready to give plenty of advice on techniques for effective composition.</p>
<p class="footer-caption">Main image: Ptolemaic armillary sphere by Richard Glynne, c. 1715. This is a representation of the heavens with the Earth at its centre. (Wh.0784)<br />Image credit: Whipple Museum of the History of Science, University of Cambridge</p>
            
        </div>
    
    

                             </div>

    <div class="visualClear"><!-- --></div>

                </div>

$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});

    <label for="header-search" class="hidden">Search site</label>
    <div class="campl-search-input">
      <form action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
      
        <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></form>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>
	</div>
		<div class="campl-row campl-global-navigation-drawer">

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">	
			<div class="campl-column12 campl-home-link-container">
				<a href="" >Home</a>
			</div>
		</div>
		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">		
			<div class="campl-column12 campl-global-navigation-mobile-list campl-global-navigation-list">
				<div class="campl-global-navigation-outer clearfix" id="study-with-us">
					<ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-global-navigation-header-container ">
						<li><a href="http://www.cam.ac.uk/study-at-cambridge" >Study at Cambridge</a></li>
					</ul>
					<div class="campl-column4">
						<ul class="campl-global-navigation-container campl-unstyled-list campl-global-navigation-secondary-with-children">

<a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/students/partii-guide/bbs">BBS options</a>
</li>
</ul></li>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix campl-page-sub-title campl-recessed-sub-title">
			<div class="campl-column3 campl-spacing-column">
				 
			</div>
			<div class="campl-column9">
				<div class="campl-content-container">
					<h1 class="campl-sub-title">
                    Introducing History and Philosophy of Science
                </h1>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div><div class="campl-row campl-content campl-recessed-content">
			<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
				<div class="campl-column3">
					
  <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation">
    <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation-structure">
      <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb"><li><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk" title="Department of History and Philosophy of Science">
            Department of History and Philosophy of Science
            <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
        </a></li>
        
          <li>
            <a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study" class="campl-parent-page" title="Study HPS">
              Study HPS
              <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
            </a>
          </li>
        
      </ul><ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-navigation"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate"><span>Undergraduate study</span></a>
<ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-children navTree navTreeLevel1"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/introducing" class=" navTreeCurrentItem"><span>Introducing History and Philosophy of Science</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/students"><span>What our students say</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/faqs"><span>Frequently asked questions</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/routes"><span>Routes into History and Philosophy of Science</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partib"><span>Part IB</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partii"><span>Part II</span></a>
</li>
<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partiii"><span>Part III</span></a>
</li>
</ul></li>

</li>

      </ul></div>
  </div>

				</div>
				<div class="campl-column9 campl-main-content" id="campl-content"><div class="clearfix campl-carousel" id="campl-carousel">
        
      </div><div class="campl-content-container">

            <div id="viewlet-above-content">
</div>

            
                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-55815e3aef7e41caba142b73705a7a1d">
            <p class="first">Technology, medicine and the sciences shape and dominate much of modern life. Many get specialist training in these fields. Even more people live in a world where the results of scientific inquiry and technical programmes matter. The challenges of learning and applying scientific techniques and principles raise fundamental and exciting questions about our ways of understanding the world.</p>
<p>It is crucial that as citizens we are as well equipped as possible to understand and debate how these enterprises work and what they mean. We need to know how the sciences achieved their position in our society. We must be able to make sense of the processes of scientific knowledge, technological projects and medical strategies. We should be able to see how and why these enterprises exert their powers and how they are trusted, contested and changed.</p>
<p><img src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/front-page-carousel/foetus-1723" alt="Diagram of a foetus by Justin Dittrich Siegmund, 1723 (Image credit: Wellcome Library, London)" width="100%" class="image-inline" title="Diagram of a foetus by Justin Dittrich Siegmund, 1723 (Image credit: Wellcome Library, London)" /></p>
<p>The courses offered by the Department of History and Philosophy of Science (HPS) furnish resources to achieve this. Students are trained to employ techniques from history, philosophy and the social sciences. Students with a background in natural sciences or medicine learn how to put their work into its wider context and to ask more fundamental questions about their approach and achievement. Those from history, philosophy and the social sciences learn more about the essential roles and developments of the sciences, medicine and technology in the world. With these techniques, they are taught how to follow the ways in which sciences, technology and medicine changed and how to appreciate the way they function now.</p>
<p>Many of the most urgent public problems facing us now rely on very basic claims about how we get reliable knowledge and whom we should trust. Fraught debates about the causes of climate change or the safety of genetically modified foods, about the validity of techniques drawn from complementary medicine or the authority of evolutionary explanations of human behaviour, all involve deep questions about the character of dependable knowledge.</p>
<p>Courses in HPS help students think about these questions as they occur in the major debates around the sciences. Such controversies often call on citizens to ask about the truth of the claims made by scientists, medical practitioners or technologists. We can examine whether the sciences are in fact in the business of providing certain truths about the world, or whether, instead, their task is just to generate better predictions. Many current conflicts, whether in health care or engineering, in criminology or ecology, involve assertions and assumptions about the underlying causes of apparently evident effects. So as scientists and citizens we need to understand the diverse ways in which causation works. We also inquire about how different authorities have given reasons to trust what scientists say. This requires us to figure out the conditions for accepting some claim about nature and to see how persuasion works. Often, we rely on what others tell us. What we believe may well be contradicted by others' accounts. HPS programmes offer many fascinating approaches to understanding what is going on in such cases.</p>
<p>So we depend on good pictures of the sources and methods by which we find out about the world. For a long time, the sciences have been taken to be the model of secure knowledge. Students in HPS learn how to explore such models and how they have changed. These changes have taken place in surprising and provocative ways. HPS courses study models of knowledge across many societies and periods. There are many more systems of making knowledge than those pursued in modern technological societies. So students can learn about the knowledge systems and practical enterprises of other cultures, including classical China, ancient Mesopotamia or medieval Christendom. One vital aim is to explore the world-views of other communities, to make sense of approaches very different from those of industrial societies. Students also examine how these systems acquire their impressive power to act in the world. This means we have to ask why it is believed that the sciences are in fact such a potent way of understanding the world around us.</p>
<p>The task of scientific understanding has been, and is now, achieved through a range of very contrasting approaches. These include experiment and measurement, meditation and observation, classification and artistry. In different places and at different times highly variable methods have been put to work to establish how nature works and to manage and manipulate it. The purposes that guide human communities in the development of natural knowledge and of sophisticated techniques are also highly disparate. It makes a difference if nature is seen as a result of divine creation or instead as a vast, self-sustaining machine. It also makes a difference if the trustworthy interpreters of nature are treated as priests or as engineers.</p>
<p>So one of the most important questions about the sciences is their relation with the wider social system. Technologies and sciences in the modern world rely on massive networks of social organisation and communal enterprise. One way of thinking about the sciences is to treat them as institutions, then study the groups that make knowledge work, check its validity, train its practitioners and give it value. HPS courses help students learn how to apply this approach to the sciences, to medicine and to technology. These courses let students debate the urgent questions of the collective and individual character of reliable knowledge and effective technique.</p>
<p>The same kinds of fascinating and important issues arise in medical experience. Different peoples give very contrasting senses to the principal events of human life and death. Students of HPS explore how the medicalisation of these events was effected. They study the relations between notions of well-being and health, social life and individual fate, as models of medical intervention and of the human body have been contested, revised and developed. There have been close connexions between attitudes to technologies and to medical strategies. These have shaped the status of physicians and health carers, they matter to the condition of men and women in society and to the imagination of what counts as a good life. Courses in HPS allow students to investigate these fundamental social, ethical and historical problems and to learn how to analyse the condition of the biomedical world and its meanings.</p>
<p>The HPS department offers its students the chance to gain important insights about the condition of the sciences, of technology and of medicine. It also trains them in techniques of interpretation and argument, communication and critical analysis. These are indispensable skills throughout the Tripos. They are also increasingly valuable in an epoch when social, biomedical and environmental transformations pose such major challenges to public knowledge and expert authority. Graduates from the Department have successfully won places as researchers and activists, science educators and journalists, exhibition curators and media professionals and experts in science and technology policy. <strong>Join us in this programme!</strong></p>
<div class="info-box-full">
<h2 style="padding-top: 0; ">Suggested reading</h2>
<p>To find out more about HPS, try some of these books:</p>
<ul><li>Peter Bowler and Iwan Morus, <em>Making Modern Science</em> (University of Chicago Press, 2005)</li>
<li>H.M. Collins and Trevor Pinch, <em>The Golem: What You Should Know About Science</em> (Cambridge University Press, 1998)</li>
<li>Jeff Hughes, <em>The Manhattan Project: Big Science and the Atomic Bomb</em> (Icon, 2003)</li>
<li>T.S. Kuhn, <em>The Structure of Scientific Revolutions</em> (University of Chicago Press, 1996)</li>
<li>Bas van Fraassen, <em>The Scientific Image</em> (Clarendon Press, 1980)</li>
<li>James Watson, <em>The Double Helix</em> (Longman, 2001)</li>
</ul></div>
<p class="footer-caption">Main image: Diagram of a foetus by Justin Dittrich Siegmund, 1723<br />Image credit: Wellcome Library, London</p>
            
        </div>
    
    

                             </div>
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-body">





    <div class="visualClear"><!-- --></div>

    <div class="documentActions">
        

        

    </div>

</div>

                            
                        </div>
                    

                    
                </div>
            

            <div id="viewlet-below-content">





</div>
        </div></div>
				
			</div>	
		</div><div class="campl-row campl-local-footer" id="falcon-local-footer">
  <div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
    <div class="campl-column3 campl-footer-navigation">

$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});
</script></body></html>

    <div class="campl-search-input">
      <form action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
      
        <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></form>

			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>

			<div class="campl-column3 campl-spacing-column">
