			<div class="campl-column9">
				<div class="campl-content-container">
					<h1 class="campl-sub-title">
                    Part IB
                </h1>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div><div class="campl-row campl-content campl-recessed-content">
			<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
				<div class="campl-column3">
					
  <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation">
    <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation-structure">
      <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb"><li><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk" title="Department of History and Philosophy of Science">
            Department of History and Philosophy of Science
            <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
        </a></li>
        
          <li>
            <a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study" class="campl-parent-page" title="Study HPS">
              Study HPS
              <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
            </a>
          </li>
        
      </ul><ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-navigation"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate"><span>Undergraduate study</span></a>

				</div>
				<div class="campl-column6  campl-main-content" id="campl-content"><div class="clearfix campl-carousel" id="campl-carousel">
        
          <div class="campl-carousel-container">
            <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-slides"><li class="campl-slide campl-column12">
  <div class="image-container">
    
      <img alt="dna-model.jpg" class="campl-scale-with-grid" src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/carousel/dna-model/@@images/34969a1a-538f-414e-ac2d-fab804103f73.jpeg" title="A replica of Watson and Crick's DNA model" /></div>
  

</li>
            </ul></div>
        
      </div><div class="campl-content-container">

            <div id="viewlet-above-content">
</div>

            
                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-ef20f7036a0c4cb1b6a9e23c3d90087d">
            <p class="first">The Part IB course in History and Philosophy of Science offers a wide-ranging overview of the nature of science and its place in society. The course explores the historical, philosophical and social dimensions of the sciences, the ways in which the sciences are shaped by other aspects of social and economic life, and the role of scientists in public debate.</p>
<p>Examples are drawn from many different disciplines, over a period extending from the Renaissance to the present day: from early astronomy, alchemy and natural philosophy, to the atomic bomb and the discovery of DNA. We examine questions about how theories are tested and change, and about the nature of causation, laws and scientific explanation. The course also considers whether science provides an increasingly accurate account of a largely unobservable world.</p>
<p>No previous experience in history or philosophy is expected; the lectures and basic reading provide the necessary background.</p>
<p>In addition to encouraging a broad perspective on the sciences, the course develops skills of writing, reading and critical thinking. These skills are essential if you are to make effective use of your other Tripos options.</p>
<div class="info-box-full">
<p>HPS Part IB is also available as an option for students taking Part IIA of the Human, Social and Political Sciences Tripos (HSPS) and the Psychological and Behavioural Sciences Tripos (PBS). These students choose only one paper: History of Science (shown on CamSIS as HPS1) or Philosophy of Science (HPS2). Natural Sciences Tripos students take both papers.</p>
</div>
<p class="footer-caption">Main image: A replica of Watson and Crick's DNA model</p>
            
        </div>
    
    

                             </div>
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-body">





    <div class="visualClear"><!-- --></div>

    <div class="documentActions">
        

        

    </div>

</div>

                            
                        </div>
                    

                    
                </div>
            

            <div id="viewlet-below-content">





</div>
        </div></div>

							<a href="https://www.philanthropy.cam.ac.uk/">Give to Cambridge</a>

					</ul>
				</div>
			</div>

				<div class="campl-content-container campl-navigation-list">

<![endif]--><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/libs/ios-orientationchange-fix.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/libs/modernizr.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/custom.js"></script><script type="text/javascript">
$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});
</script></body></html>

			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>

<ul class="campl-unstyled-list"><li>
 <a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk"> <span>Home</span></a>

<li>
<a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/about">About the Department</a>
<ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-local-dropdown-menu"><li><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/about">About the Department Overview</a></li>

<a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/about/research-projects">Research projects</a>
<ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-local-dropdown-menu"><li><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/about/research-projects">Research projects Overview</a></li>
<li>
<a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/about/research-projects/seeds-for-survival">Seeds for Survival: A Global History of Seed Banking</a>
</li>

<a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/about/research-projects/fake-instruments">Investigating Fake Scientific Instruments in the Whipple Museum Collection</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/about/research-projects/before-hiv">Before HIV: Homosex and Venereal Disease, c.1939–1984</a>

			<div class="campl-column9">
				<div class="campl-content-container">
					<h1 class="campl-sub-title">
                    Part II
                </h1>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div><div class="campl-row campl-content campl-recessed-content">
			<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
				<div class="campl-column3">
					
  <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation">
    <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation-structure">
      <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb"><li><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk" title="Department of History and Philosophy of Science">
            Department of History and Philosophy of Science
            <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
        </a></li>
        
          <li>
            <a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study" class="campl-parent-page" title="Study HPS">
              Study HPS
              <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
            </a>
          </li>
        
      </ul><ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-navigation"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate"><span>Undergraduate study</span></a>

				<div class="campl-column6  campl-main-content" id="campl-content"><div class="clearfix campl-carousel" id="campl-carousel">
        
          <div class="campl-carousel-container">
            <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-slides"><li class="campl-slide campl-column12">
  <div class="image-container">
    
      <img alt="sherburne-instruments.jpg" class="campl-scale-with-grid" src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/carousel/sherburne-instruments/@@images/16f950f8-171d-4116-b67e-c4dc7beedf8b.jpeg" title="Detail from Edward Sherburne, 'The sphere of Marcus Manilius made an English poem', 1675 (Image credit: Whipple Library, University of Cambridge)" /></div>
  

</li>
            </ul></div>
        
      </div><div class="campl-content-container">

            <div id="viewlet-above-content">
</div>

            
                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-90afd3e5f46c43a3bd9f984cd4400b5e">
            <p class="first">The Part II course in History and Philosophy of Science (HPS) gives students an insight into the historical development of science, medicine and technology. It addresses questions about the nature of scientific knowledge, and critically examines the social authority given to scientific expertise. It thus provides essential intellectual resources for understanding some of the most important aspects of modern society and culture.</p>
<p>This is a full-time Part II course in the Natural Sciences Tripos. We also offer <a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/students/timetable/partii/single" class="internal-link" target="_self">single-paper options</a> as part of the NST Part II course in Biological and Biomedical Sciences, Part IIB of the Human, Social and Political Sciences Tripos, and Part IIB of the Psychological and Behavioural Sciences Tripos.</p>
<h2 id="options">Options</h2>
<p>There are two alternative ways of designing your HPS Part II programme.</p>
<p><strong>Option A</strong> consists of:</p>
<ul><li>three unseen written examinations chosen from a broad range of papers</li>
<li>a dissertation;</li>
<li>two primary source essays.</li>
</ul><p><strong>Option B</strong> consists of:</p>
<ul><li>four unseen written examinations chosen from a broad range of papers;</li>
<li>two primary source essays.</li>
</ul><p>Each examination paper counts for 20%, the two primary source essays for 20% and the dissertation (in Option A) for 20% of the overall mark. This means that Option A is 40% coursework and Option B is 20% coursework.</p>
<h2 id="the_papers">The papers</h2>
<p>Students choose from the following list of papers. Any combination of papers will provide a very broad exposure to the field of history and philosophy of science and medicine and will fully meet the course aims and objectives.</p>
<ul><li>Paper 1: Early Science and Medicine</li>
<li>Paper 2: Sciences in Transition: Renaissance to Enlightenment</li>
<li>Paper 3: Science, Medicine and Empire</li>
<li>Paper 4: Science, Medicine and Technology since 1900</li>
<li>Paper 5: Philosophy of Science</li>
<li>Paper 6: Ethics and Politics of Science, Technology and Medicine</li>
</ul><h2 id="primary_sources">Primary sources</h2>
<p>All students write two extended essays (up to 3,000 words), each focused on an assigned primary source. During Michaelmas Term there will be six series of primary source seminars, each made up of four seminars. Students should attend four series of seminars. They then choose two sources on which to write their essays.</p>
<p>The prescribed sources for 2017–18 are as follows:</p>
<ul><li>Franz Boas, <em>The Mind of Primitive Man</em> (New York: Macmillan, 1911; 2nd ed. 1938)</li>
<li>The Stanford School:
<ul><li>John Dupré, <em>The Disorder of Things: Metaphysical Foundations of the Disunity of Science</em> (Cambridge, MA &amp; London: Harvard University Press, 1993), chapter 10, 'The Disunity of Science', pp. 221–243</li>
<li>Ian Hacking, 'Do we see through a microscope?', <em>Pacific Philosophical Quarterly</em> 62 (1981): 305–322; it is also reprinted essentially in the same form as chapter 11 of Hacking's <em>Representing and Intervening</em></li>
<li>Nancy Cartwright, 'Fundamentalism versus the patchwork of laws', chapter 1 of <em>The Dappled World: A Study in Boundaries of Science</em> (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1999); previously published in <em>Proceedings of the Aristotelian Society</em> 94 (1994): 279–292</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Hans Reichenbach, <em>The Direction of Time</em> (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1971)</li>
<li>Jan van der Straet (Stradanus), <em>Nova Reperta</em> (New Inventions), a series of 20 engravings, c. 1590</li>
<li><a href="https://www.lib.noaa.gov/collections/foreign_climate_data_pages/foreign_climate_data_china.html#o39974593" title="NOAA Central Library">Medical Reports of the Chinese Imperial Maritime Customs Service</a></li>
<li>Claus Pias, <em>Cybernetics: The Macy Conferences 1946–1953 – The Complete Transactions</em> (Zurich: Diaphanes, 2016)</li>
</ul><h2 id="dissertation">Dissertation</h2>
<p>This part of the course – which is only for students taking Option A – gives students the chance to explore in depth a topic that really interests them. The dissertation is a substantial piece of original work (up to 12,000 words). Students make short presentations on their dissertation work in dissertation seminars in Lent Term.</p>
<h2 id="supervisions">Supervisions</h2>
<p>All papers are supported by supervisions; we recommend that students write 6–8 supervision essays per paper.</p>
<p class="footer-caption">Main image: Detail from Edward Sherburne, <em>The sphere of Marcus Manilius made an English poem</em>, 1675<br />Image credit: Whipple Library, University of Cambridge</p>
            
        </div>

<div class="portletWrapper" data-portlethash="706c6f6e652e7269676874636f6c756d6e0a636f6e746578740a2f4850534d41494e2f73747564792f756e64657267726164756174652f7061727469690a6c696e6b73" id="portletwrapper-706c6f6e652e7269676874636f6c756d6e0a636f6e746578740a2f4850534d41494e2f73747564792f756e64657267726164756174652f7061727469690a6c696e6b73"><div class="campl-content-container falcon-linkbox-portlet">

$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});
</script></body></html>

    <label for="header-search" class="hidden">Search site</label>
    <div class="campl-search-input">
      <form action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
      
        <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></form>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>
	</div>

</li>

		</div>



		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix campl-page-sub-title campl-recessed-sub-title">
			<div class="campl-column3 campl-spacing-column">

			<div class="campl-column9">
				<div class="campl-content-container">
					<h1 class="campl-sub-title">
                    Part III
                </h1>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div><div class="campl-row campl-content campl-recessed-content">
			<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
				<div class="campl-column3">
					
  <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation">
    <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation-structure">

				</div>
				<div class="campl-column6  campl-main-content" id="campl-content"><div class="clearfix campl-carousel" id="campl-carousel">
        
          <div class="campl-carousel-container">
            <ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-slides"><li class="campl-slide campl-column12">
  <div class="image-container">
    
      <img alt="tintometer-t338.jpg" class="campl-scale-with-grid" src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/carousel/tintometer-t338/@@images/75a9b37b-ce80-4998-ba61-f579d30da8d2.jpeg" title="Tintometer slides, Lovibond, c. 1910. Originally used in the brewing industry, the tintometer is an instrument that assisted manufacturers in measuring and standardising colour. (T338) (Image credit: Whipple Museum of the History of Science, University of Cambridge)" /></div>
  

</li>
            </ul></div>
        
      </div><div class="campl-content-container">

            <div id="viewlet-above-content">
</div>

            
                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-f83497b16c434e49bf85709cf94c4a3d">
            <p class="first">The Department's Part III course is conducted by means of supervisions and seminars. Students are also encouraged to attend some of the wide range of relevant lectures offered in the Department and elsewhere in the University.</p>
<p>The Part III course requires students to submit:</p>
<ul><li>two essays, each of no more than 5,000 words;</li>
<li>two essays, each of not more than 2,500 words, on subjects chosen from a published list of subjects;</li>
<li>a dissertation, of no more than 15,000 words.</li>
</ul><p>Work for each essay and the dissertation will be separately supervised by senior members and associates of the Department.</p>
<p>Part III students are encouraged to explore a range of different topics, balancing them so that they are both relevant to their interests and also span the subject of History, Philosophy and Sociology of Science, Technology and Medicine. Discussions between the Part III Manager and each student are intended to ensure that all students follow an appropriate, individualised and sufficiently broad course of study; the formal approval of topics of essays and dissertation by the Degree Committee is intended to provide oversight of this procedure.</p>
<h2>Two essays of 5,000 words</h2>
<p>The first of these two essays is a <strong>Research Paper</strong> on a topic chosen in discussion with a supervisor in the first weeks of Michaelmas Term. For this essay, students are encouraged to undertake original research in any area within the History, Philosophy and Sociology of Science, Technology and Medicine. The topic of the essay must be submitted for approval in early November. It is due for submission at the end of Michaelmas Term.</p>
<p>The second 5,000-word essay is a <strong>Critical Literature Review</strong> on a topic chosen in discussion with a supervisor. The topic of the essay must be submitted for approval at the end of Michaelmas Term. It is due for submission at the end of Lent Term (i.e. mid-March).</p>
<h2>Two essays of 2,500 words</h2>
<p>Every Part III student should attend regularly the Part III seminar, which meets on Wednesdays during term at 3pm. During the first term, and at the beginning of the second term, these seminars are led by different senior members of the Department, and focus on selected readings in history, philosophy and sociology of science, technology and medicine. In addition to reading the texts prescribed for each seminar and discussing them in the seminar, students will be offered up to five supervisions with senior members or associates of the Department on the seminar readings, principally during Michaelmas Term, and will write a number of brief essays for discussion in supervision. In Lent Term, a list of subjects will be published relating to the topics covered in the Part III seminar. Students will be asked to choose two topics from this list on which to write the two essays of 2,500 words, which will be submitted by the half-way point (the division, i.e. mid-February) of Lent Term.</p>
<h2>Dissertation</h2>
<p>Students are permitted to write their dissertation in the same general area as one of their essays. In such cases, the dissertation and essay have to address different questions, and the dissertation must give evidence of a substantial new research effort. Students may take the opportunity of working on the Critical Literature Review to make an initial exploration of the important questions and themes in the field in which they intend to write their dissertation. The topic of the dissertation must be submitted for approval at the end of February.</p>
<h2>Part III teaching</h2>
<p>The Part III programme is administered by a senior member of staff, the Part III Manager, who meets all new Part III students as a group in early October, then sees each of the students individually to discuss their proposed essay and dissertation topics. The Manager is responsible for finding appropriate supervisors for each of these topics; the supervisors are then responsible for helping the student do the research and writing needed for the essays and the dissertation. Students will see each of their supervisors on a very regular basis; the Part III Manager sees each student at regular intervals during the year to discuss progress and offer help and advice. Supervisions are designed to provide students with the opportunity to set their own agenda for their studies. The supervisor's job is to support the student's research, not to grade their work – supervisors are formally excluded from the examination process.</p>
<p>If problems arise with research or supervision, students should talk to their supervisors, or to the Part III Manager, or to the Secretary of the Degree Committee. The Director of Graduate Studies will be happy to advise Part III students planning to go on to PhD research. All Part III students must be resident in Cambridge throughout the duration of the course.</p>
<h2>Seminars and lectures</h2>
<p>The Part III seminar is the core teaching resource for the course. During the second half of the second term, and during the third term, the seminars provide opportunities for Part III students to present their own work. Students are also strongly encouraged to attend the Departmental Seminar and other seminars, workshops and reading groups arranged regularly by the Department. Graduate training workshops, which run throughout the academic year, focus on key research, presentation, publication and employment skills.</p>
<p>Part III students are also strongly encouraged to attend some of the HPS Part II lectures for the papers they did not take the previous year, as well as relevant lectures and seminars held in other departments and faculties in the University. The Part III Manager and the supervisors will help indicate the lectures and seminars close to each student's interests.</p>
<h2>Admission criteria</h2>
<p>Students should email their application to hpshod@hermes.cam.ac.uk by 16 March 2018. Applications should consist of the following:</p>
<ul><li>A one-page statement of interests.</li>
<li>The student's unofficial transcript from CamSIS.</li>
<li>A work sample (this can be an essay or dissertation written during the Part II).</li>
<li>A letter of support from the student's College confirming that they support the student's intention to take HPS Part III, and arrangements are in place for a fourth year of study.</li>
<li>A reference from the current Director of Studies.</li>
</ul><p><strong>For those who have taken HPS Part II:</strong> the Department will normally expect students to obtain a 2:1 in their Part II exams.</p>
<p><strong>For those who have <em>not</em> taken HPS Part II:</strong> the Department considers applications on a case-by-case basis. Students will normally be expected to obtain a high 2:1 in their Part II exams, and may be interviewed by a senior member of the Department.</p>
<p>Although their results will be published at the end of the Part II, students going on to the Part III must not graduate after their third year exams and will receive their BA once they have completed the Part III course, along with their MSci (assuming satisfactory performance in the Part III). Any student who in June remains unsure about whether or not they will be going on to the Part III will still have the opportunity to graduate in July.</p>
<p>There is a quota of 12 places for this course. <strong>If the course is oversubscribed, meeting the admissions criteria may not be sufficient to secure a place</strong> because if the number of applicants exceeds the quota there will be a ranking procedure. All plans to continue to HPS Part III must therefore be provisional until a place has been confirmed.</p>
<p>A preliminary shortlist will be decided upon in Easter Term, but the final decision on who will be offered a place will not be taken until after the Part II tripos results are announced. Letters will then be sent to all students informing them of the decision and telling those who are offered places on the Part III course that they should ensure their Colleges withdraw their names from those who will graduate.</p>
<p>The NST Committee has updated the entry requirements for Part III and any appeals for acceptance may in future be dealt with by the Applications Committee.</p>
<p class="footer-caption">Main image: Tintometer slides, Lovibond, c. 1910. Originally used in the brewing industry, the tintometer is an instrument that assisted manufacturers in measuring and standardising colour. (T338)<br />Image credit: Whipple Museum of the History of Science, University of Cambridge</p>
            
        </div>

$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});

    <label for="header-search" class="hidden">Search site</label>
    <div class="campl-search-input">
      <form action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
      
        <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></form>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix campl-page-sub-title campl-recessed-sub-title">
			<div class="campl-column3 campl-spacing-column">
				 
			</div>
			<div class="campl-column9">
				<div class="campl-content-container">
					<h1 class="campl-sub-title">
                    Routes into History and Philosophy of Science
                </h1>
				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div><div class="campl-row campl-content campl-recessed-content">
			<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
				<div class="campl-column3">
					
  <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation">
    <div class="campl-tertiary-navigation-structure">

        </a></li>
        
          <li>
            <a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study" class="campl-parent-page" title="Study HPS">
              Study HPS
              <span class="campl-vertical-breadcrumb-indicator"></span>
            </a>
          </li>
        
      </ul><ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-navigation"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected navTreeFolderish"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate"><span>Undergraduate study</span></a>
<ul class="campl-unstyled-list campl-vertical-breadcrumb-children navTree navTreeLevel1"><li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/introducing"><span>Introducing History and Philosophy of Science</span></a>

<li class="navTreeItem visualNoMarker campl-selected"><a href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/routes" class=" navTreeCurrentItem"><span>Routes into History and Philosophy of Science</span></a>

				<div class="campl-column9 campl-main-content" id="campl-content"><div class="clearfix campl-carousel" id="campl-carousel">
        
      </div><div class="campl-content-container">

            <div id="viewlet-above-content">
</div>

            
                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-32965688c6554d6eaa1a4518ee138229">
            <h2 style="padding-top: 0; ">Part IB</h2>
<p><strong>Natural Sciences Tripos (NST):</strong> We welcome everyone who wants to take HPS Part IB. At the present time there is no upper limit; total numbers taking the course range from 65 to 100. NST students take both HPS Part IB papers – History of Science and Philosophy of Science – expect for students taking Part IB Physics who can chose a single paper.</p>
<p><strong>Psychological and Behavioural Sciences Tripos (PBS) and Human, Social and Political Sciences Tripos (HSPS):</strong> Students are able to take one of the two HPS Part IB papers as part of their Part IIA course: History of Science (HPS1) or Philosophy of Science (HPS2).</p>
<p><a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partib" class="internal-link campl-primary-cta" target="_self">More about HPS Part IB</a></p>
<h2>Part II</h2>
<h3>HPS Part II</h3>
<p><strong>NST and other triposes:</strong> There is a quota of 40, and admission can be competitive. A Part II allocations meeting takes place in late June every year. Most of the places are filled at this point and to ensure a place students need to make their choices known on CamSIS.</p>
<p>Our policy is to try to offer a Part II place to everyone who has taken HPS Part IB. A 2:1 is normally expected from other students. Tripos switchers who are underperforming are not admitted unless there is strong evidence that they will perform well in HPS. No place should be assumed without checking first.</p>
<p><a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partii" class="internal-link campl-primary-cta" target="_self">More about HPS Part II</a></p>
<h3>Single-paper options</h3>
<p><strong>Biological and Biomedical Sciences minor subjects:</strong> We welcome all students who wish to take one of our single-paper options: Philosophy and Ethics of Medicine, Early Medicine, or Modern Medicine and Biomedical Sciences.</p>
<p><strong>PBS and HSPS</strong>: PBS and HSPS Part IIB students can take one of the HPS Part II papers. PBS students can choose Philosophy of Science (Paper 5) or Modern Medicine and Biomedical Sciences. HSPS students can choose Philosophy of Science (Paper 5) or Ethics and Politics of Science, Technology and Medicine (Paper 6).</p>
<p><a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/students/timetable/partii/single" class="internal-link campl-primary-cta" target="_self">More about single-paper options</a></p>
<h2>Part III</h2>
<p><strong>NST and other triposes:</strong> There is a quota of 12, and admission is competitive. Students must make an application to the Department by mid-March, and we make preliminary offers by the end of Easter Term. It is not necessary to have taken HPS Part II: we have had students from a variety of triposes, including English and History as well as NST.</p>
<p><a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/partiii" class="internal-link campl-primary-cta" target="_self">More about HPS Part III</a></p>
<h2>MPhil and PhD</h2>
<p>All applicants must complete the online application form. The Director of Studies is expected to advise on potential areas of expertise, to support the student in identifying sources of financial support and, where opportunities arise, to liaise between the College and the Department to put together a viable funding package.</p>
<p><a title="" href="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/study/graduate" class="internal-link campl-primary-cta" target="_self">More about graduate study</a></p>
            
        </div>
    
    

                             </div>

$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});

		<div class="campl-wrap clearfix">
			<form class="campl-site-search-form" id="site-search-container" action="https://search.cam.ac.uk/web">
    <div class="campl-search-form-wrapper clearfix">
      <input id="header-search" type="text" placeholder="Search" name="query" size="18" title="Search Site" class="text search-autocomplete" /><input type="image" class="campl-search-submit " src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/images/interface/btn-search-header.png" /><input type="hidden" value="HPS" name="inst" /></div>
  </form>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        /* there are two auto-completion plugins and the wrong one wins.
         * Create the jQuery UI widget *directly* by instanciating a widget 
         * for each object manually, adding it to the element data.
         */
        var widget = $.ui.autocomplete,
            fullname = 'ui-autocomplete',
            search_inst = $('#site-search-btn input[type=hidden][name=inst]').val(),
            options = {
                source: function(request, response) {
                    $.ajax({
                        url: "http://api.search.cam.ac.uk/suggest",
                        dataType: "jsonp",
                        data: { term: request.term, inst: search_inst },
                        success: response
                    })
                },
                select: function(event, ui) {
                    // Submit the form on select
                    $(this).val(ui.item.value);
                    $(this).context.form.submit();
                }
            };
        /* NB: Following jQuery selector matches mobile AND desktop views */
        $("input.search-autocomplete").each(function () {
            var instance = $.data(this, fullname, new widget(options, this));
        });
    </script>
		</div>
	</div>
		<div class="campl-row campl-global-navigation-drawer">

					<h1 class="campl-sub-title">
                    What our students say
                </h1>

                <div class="">

                    

                    

    <dl class="portalMessage info" id="kssPortalMessage" style="display:none"><dt>Info</dt>
        <dd></dd>
    </dl><div id="content">

                            

                            

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-title">


</div>
                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             
                             <div id="viewlet-below-content-title">
</div>

                             
                                 
                                 
            
                
            
            
        
                             

                             <div id="viewlet-above-content-body">



</div>
                             <div id="content-core">
                                 
    
        
        <div class="" id="parent-fieldname-text-eff6c831f9af402bbf433a3b7ae744e8">
            <p class="first">We asked some recent students to tell us about their experience of studying History and Philosophy of Science. Here are their responses.</p>
<h2>Jill</h2>
<blockquote class="clearfix embed-quote-full">Studying HPS has been an immensely rewarding experience for me.</blockquote>
<p><img src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/miscellaneous/jill" alt="jill.jpg" class="image-right" title="Jill" />I came to Cambridge intending to be a physicist, but soon realised that I was more interested in the human aspects of science and the philosophical implications than the facts and theories themselves. Part IB HPS opened my eyes to a whole world of fascinating and diverse topics and introduced me to more critical and informed ways of thinking. I also enjoyed learning to communicate my own ideas and contribute to debates, something that I had never been able to do as an undergraduate in the sciences.</p>
<p>Having enjoyed Part IB so much, I didn't hesitate to choose HPS at Part II. It wasn't an easy option, despite what many DOSs and other people think. The work load was challenging, but the intellectual rewards were immeasurable. Reading lots of books and writing essays were skills that I hadn't used much as a scientist, but it was surprisingly easy to adapt and I actually found it all very enjoyable. I chose a range of papers covering history, philosophy and sociology and every lecture course influenced the way I think about science and society. I've since gone on to do an MPhil in HPS and publish my own research in an academic journal, and I'm about to train as a science teacher, so my HPS background will be more valuable than ever. I enjoyed every minute of working in this friendly, supportive and vibrant department. HPS has something for everyone and I thoroughly recommend it."</p>
<h2>Mike</h2>
<blockquote class="clearfix embed-quote-full">HPS certainly wasn't what I envisaged studying when I came to Cambridge!</blockquote>
<p><img src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/miscellaneous/mike" alt="mike.jpg" class="image-right" title="Mike" />As a NatSci I took physical sciences in my first year but found the excessive detail a little tedious. When I heard about HPS IB I knew that it had the potential to satisfy my interest in 'the big questions'. It has certainly delivered. At IB I took HPS, maths and pscyhology, and they worked really well together as they were a nice mix of types of thinking. HPS IB was a breath of fresh air offering both content and learning methods that I had never really encountered before. The increased freedom afforded, and the discipline required by such a subject was liberating and valuable. IB interested me sufficiently that I went on to take the philosophical papers at Part II.</p>
<p>Part II HPS improved upon what I had enjoyed most at IB – fascinating yet flexible content and much more independent learning, as well as an opportunity, with the dissertation, to try your hand at research. There is such a wide set of options on offer that anyone with a deeper interest in science will find plenty to keep them engrossed, and the supervisors are all really personable and helpful. It really is an enjoyable department to be a part of – big enough to be exciting, small enough to be personal. I have learnt valuable study skills, advanced my self-discipline and met some fascinating people. Now entering my third year of a PhD in the philosophy of science I am very glad I took the chance offered at IB to try something new."</p>
<h2>Jenny</h2>
<blockquote class="clearfix embed-quote-full">The range of subjects covered in HPS is incredibly diverse...</blockquote>
<p><img src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/miscellaneous/jenny" alt="jenny.jpg" class="image-right" title="Jenny" />...and many people probably don't realise (as I didn't) just how many subject matters, types of history, places and spaces fall under the HPS umbrella. HPS laps the boundaries of so many other subjects, not just the obvious ones but literature, psychology, classics, law... the list goes on. It is a privilege to study a course like this for Part II and, whilst it does not make you omniscient, it means you can stick your nose into friends' subjects and attempt to sound vaguely knowledgeable in some areas. It also means that you will invariably find something that really grips your imagination and you can tailor your supervisions, coursework and exam revision around things that genuinely interest you.</p>
<p>Although I chose this Part II for the history papers, my greatest challenge and probably therefore the most rewarding part of the course for me was the History and Philosophy of Mind paper. I found this subject fascinating, a nightmare to write essays on, but brilliant to talk about to all and sundry. Most of the topics were completely alien to me, specifically the philosophy of mind modules, and whilst flummoxed at first, by the end of the year I was totally engaged. One of the brilliant aspects of a one-year course like this is the opportunity to discover new subjects of study. At the beginning of the year I was also daunted by the dissertation but this was far more rewarding than I expected and I would urge you not to let the thought of the dissertation put you off.</p>
<p>The Department is small and very friendly; the teaching staff particularly are highly approachable. The size of the Department means that in general the quality of teaching is high and supervisors will take an individual interest in you and your work, but it does also mean that you are pretty conspicuous if trying to sneak into a lecture late. There are also numerous, numerous HPS related seminars and talks hosted by the Department or in Cambridge, and these are an added bonus providing opportunities either to go and listen to a subject of interest to you discussed in depth, or just to find out about something completely new."</p>
<h2>Leon</h2>
<blockquote class="clearfix embed-quote-full">When I came up to Cambridge to do Natural Sciences, I never imagined I would end up studying the history of science.</blockquote>
<p><img src="https://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/images/miscellaneous/leon" alt="leon.jpg" class="image-right" title="Leon" />At that time I simply thought I would continue to study chemistry, and would somehow end up with a career related to science. But that all changed when, in my second term here, I discovered HPS. I remember I was asked to fill out a form for my college, stating my three IB subjects. I clicked around the University's website, and discovered the Department's page. I have to admit I knew next to nothing about the subject at the time. But I felt that I wanted a challenge, a change of environment and style of thinking, so I decided to investigate further. I visited the Department, a cosy haven hidden in Free School Lane, wandered around the Whipple Museum with its wonderful exhibits, and attended a few IB lectures. I decided to give HPS a shot, still not entirely sure what I was getting myself into. And suddenly I find myself in the third year of my PhD...</p>
<p>The HPS courses are extremely enjoyable simply because they address questions which, I think, will at some point enter a NatSci's head. When I was doing a IA practical on Drosophila and inheritance, or playing around with Maxwell's equations, or learning about the physics behind the bomb, or looking up the Periodic Table... the questions which came up in my mind were: 'Well, how did they come up with this? What is the story behind the making of this piece of knowledge?' (a historical concern); 'Why should this experiment confirm this bit of theory?' (a philosophical concern); 'How do scientists, and the public, come to believe in what they believe?' (a sociological concern). One can either push these questions away and carry on as before – or they will continue to preoccupy one's mind, and HPS is the discipline that attempts to answer them. What also I love is the variety of courses on offer. At Part II, one can study everything from Greek and Chinese science, the history of alchemy, the Darwinian revolution, bioethics, the story of psychiatry, the 'war on cancer', the relationship between scientists and the public... all with their philosophical problems, historical concerns, and issues relevant to our thinking about the present, and the future. Intellectually, HPS is a deeply satisfying subject.</p>
<p>Friends I made here have landed into all sorts of jobs after graduation; they have become management consultants, accountants, journalists, documentary makers, museum curators, civil servants, and specialists in public relations, marketing and advertising. Many of them are benefiting from the unique experience of having undergone training in both science and humanities. A small group from my Part II year decided to take on the MPhil, and some of us moved on to the PhD when we realised we could not get enough of HPS. These days, I spend a good deal of my time uncovering magazines from the 1920s and 30s, trying to learn something about the translation of scientific knowledge, in an excellent adventure which has taken me to archives, libraries and conferences in Paris, Barcelona, Heidelberg, Berlin and New York. I am about to go to Shanghai and Beijing for four months to do more research, and to meet more scholars deeply passionate about what they do. Choosing IB HPS turned out to be one of those best serendipities in life!"</p>
            
        </div>
    
    

                             </div>

<![endif]--><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/libs/ios-orientationchange-fix.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/libs/modernizr.js"></script><script type="text/javascript" src="/++theme++ucam.falcon/light/javascripts/custom.js"></script><script type="text/javascript">
$(document).ready(function(){
    var contentWidth = $('#content').width();

    $("dl.image-inline.captioned, dl.image-left.captioned, dl.image-right.captioned").each(function() {
        var caption = $(this).find('.image-caption');
        var img     = $(this).find('img');
        var width   = img.width()
        var ratio   = (width < contentWidth) ? width / contentWidth : 1;

        $(this).removeAttr('style');
        caption.removeAttr('style');

        img.removeAttr('width');
        img.removeAttr('height');
        img.css('max-width', "100%");
        img.css('height', "auto");

        $(this).css('max-width', (ratio * 100.0) + '%');
    })
});
</script></body></html>
